thread.title_full: ‘Blu’ a wrenching look at the barrio through a mother’s eyes | Dallas Morning News

author: Churnin
title: ‘Blu’ a wrenching look at the barrio through a mother’s eyes
text:
Soledad and, later, her daughter, Gemini, stare up at the stars and down at the cracks they find in the sidewalk in Blu , an arresting Texas premiere at Cara Mía Theatre Co.
It’s as if they’re looking for a way out of the hopelessness in the barrio that chokes them like a prison in this play that won the 2010 Yale Drama Series Award for San Antonio native playwright Virginia Grise.
The limitless heavens above, even glimpsed through the smog, and bits of dirt or shoots of grass wriggling out of broken slabs offer signs of a proud ancestral past, filled with possibility, that reigned hundreds of years before their world was paved over with concrete.
We meet Soledad (a lyrical Stephanie Cleghorn Jasso) when she’s 15 and full of wonder, exploring the streets of the barrio for the first time. By the time she’s 17, she’s had her first baby and is overcome with the intensity of her feelings for him. Time jumps back and forth in this Glass Menagerie -like memory play. One minute Soledad delivers Blu. In the next he’s grown with two younger siblings.
The children’s father — gang member Eme, played by Rodney Garza with vulnerability under the machismo — goes to prison when the children are young. Soledad finds lasting love with a woman, Hailstorm (in a tender turn by Edyka Chilomé).
Together, Soledad and Hailstorm struggle to keep the children safe in a world where they must pick their way gingerly among the gangs that offer them belonging, violence that keeps them in line, and schools and authorities that treat them with suspicion.
René Moreno’s fluid direction of a vibrant cast seamlessly melds gritty action with exuberant dancing choreographed by Michelle N. Gibson. Characters express hard-to-articulate feelings for each other through these mute vignettes, which are performed to the steady tribal drumbeat of Trey Pendergrass’ musical compositions.
Chris Ramirez suggests the conflicted heart of Blu, who is torn between the joy he feels with his family and the sorrows he doesn’t know how to prevent. Edwin Aguilar expresses the confusion of Lunatico, who is unsure what step to take next. Maya Quetzali brings a quiet, mystical strength to Gemini, who tries to help her brothers by divining their connections to something mystical and healing.
Rodney Dobbs’ set, evocatively lit by Linda Blase, contrasts the world they live in, bordered with graffiti, and the elusive one they long for, with a roof where they can sit and marvel at the stars and a moon of Aztec-style carvings overhead.
Most movingly, the play helps us see the wonder and wasted potential of these wounded children through the eyes of their mother. It makes the difficulties that her children face and she cannot ease all the more wrenching.

Continues through Oct. 18 at the Latino Cultural Center, 2600 Live Oak St., Dallas. Performance reviewed was Saturday. $17. 214-516-0706. caramiatheatre.org.
